prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 survey of Cha II (The GASPS sample)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
A band 6 survey for the continuum and 3 CO isotopologues in 30 CTTS of the 4Myr old Chamaeleon II association.
The goal is to study the dispersion of dust AND gas and compare with younger (older) associations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use the widest bandwidth, 2.0 GHz, in 2 spectral windows for an aggregate total of 4.1GHz, for very good continuum sensitivity.
The CO linewidths from T Tauri disks are typically in the range 5-10 km/s, depending on inclination. We have assumed 5km/sec.
We have set the spectral resolution to 0.3km/sec per channel. This will provide about 15 channels accross a typical 5km/sec line, enough to extract good (double peaked for typical disks) line profiles. The very narrowest lines (pole-on sources) may be slightly spectrally unresolved but we will be able to measure the integrated line intensity to high sensitivity in all cases. Further, an independent check of two-channel (i.e., a single velocity resolution element) detections is possible by comparing the two polarizations.
Chamaeleon II is a quiescent cloud with a well determined cloud systemic velocity of 3km/s and narrow cloud linewidth of 1.7km/s (Mizuno et al. 2001). Based on experience in Taurus, the disk velocities are expected to be within a few km/s of the cloud velocity and we are confident that the disk emission will lie within the bandpass (with room to spare).
Our desired (gas+dust) mass sensitivity of 0.1 MJup corresponds to a continuum flux at band 6 of F230 GHz = 1.0 mJy at the 178pc distance of Chamaeleon II for an assumed gas-to-dust ratio of 100 and full radiative transfer calculation. We achieve a robust 9 sigma detection (0.11mJy/beam) in about 3 minutes per target.
Figure 2 shows a simulation of a 3-minute C36-5 Cycle 3 array integration of a disk that has a total flux 1.0 mJy and diameter 300AU at declination = -77degrees. The disk continuum emission is clearly detected and the flux is accurately recovered, but a shorter integration, equivalent to a 3sigma detection, produces less reliable result. Note that we expect our disks to be significantly brighter than this. These limits are set to provide useful upper limits in case of non detection.
This observational set-up leads to an rms of 15mJy in a 0.3km/sec channel for the lines.
The low-mass disk model of Fig. 2 produces 1.5Jy peak intensity in the brightest 0.3km/sec channel in the 12CO(2-1) line. The specified target rms aims at ensuring we can also detect the 13CO line. In our calculation the 12CO line is optically thick and the 13CO is also marginally optically thick, line ratio is 6. This will also be detected easily, the peak flux is 1500mJy / 6 = 250mJy for the 13CO line. The C18O line should be 35mJy (or brighter), assuming normal abundance ratio and optically thin 13CO and C18O lines (brighter is 13CO is thick). For the estimations, we have assumed a peak flux of 100mJy for all sources (expected for the C18O line for a slightly more massive disk than the model of Fig.2).
We can clearly detect the saturated lines and anticipate that we can detect C18O in a median model MMSN disk. The 13CO line will be detected in disks lower in mass by an order of magnitude. If no lines are detected, we can place very stringent constraints on the gas mass, 1.5 10e-4, or M = 0.1 MJup in gas (for G/D = 100)!
The sources are far enough away from each other to each require an individual pointing but close enough ( < 10 deg) to share the same gain calibrator.
The full program can be carried out in a single 2.5-hour block with all targets above 30deg elevation and minimal shadowing.

The typical linewidths for disks around solar-like T Tauri stars, like those in our sample are 5-10km/sec. We chose 5km/sec for estimations.
Typical line profiles for disks are double peaked, with peak separation depending on disk size and inclination in particular. The peak separations are usually of order 2-4 km/sec, except for very pole-on sources. We selected the spectral resolution to sample properly these double-peaked line profiles.
The maximum line width we expect (wing-to-wing, not the FWHM) is of order 20km/sec. The total bandwidth in each spectral window (150km/sec) is sufficient.

The goal of this proposal is to detect disks that were not detected before at band 6. We have good estimation of their expected continuum fluxes based on Herschel measurements at FIR wavelengths. The most appropriate configuration is the C36-5 arrangement with maximum baselines of 1150m, resulting in a beam of 0.29" x 0.43" at dec= -77deg (relevant for all Cha II targets). This is a good compromise between angular resolution to resolve the disk sizes in the gas and maybe continuum and good sensitivity to detect the fainter, lower mass disks of the sample.
A priori we do not know the size of the disks at this stage because they have never been resolved. However, by analogy with several other solar-like T Tauri disks in other star forming regions we do expect to find objects with representative outer radii of order 100AU, maybe up to 200AU (diameter 400AU) leading to an expected maximum angular size of the order of 2.25arcsec at d=178pc.
We are principally interested in measuring the total flux but information on the disk size helps narrow down the range of models for estimating gas masses. Thus, although we could achieve our science goals with a more compact configuration, we prefer an intermediate array observations. Resolved disks with sizes > 2.0" = 350 AU will have lower fluxes on longer baselines but are probably more massive than the model of Fig.2 used for estimates and thus easier to detect.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Dust in Protoplanetary disks dissipates with typical timescales of about 3 Myr. By 10Myr, very few disks are detected and little primordial material is left. The formation of gaseous planets must be complete by that time. However, this understanding is based almost entirely on measurements of the dust continuum only and assumes that the gas dissipates on the same timescale. Sadly, next to no information is available regarding the gas dispersal. The Cha II association has an estimated age of 4 Myr, at time when planet formation and disk dissipation are at full force. We propose a survey of all known K \& M stars with disks to measure the band 6 continuum and resolve the disk sizes. We also propose to observe three CO isotopologues to search for cold gas and estimate the state of gas dissipation. The sample is carefully selected and will be readily comparable, including gas {\it and} dust for the first time, with younger associations with minimum biases.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is the re-submission of Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00708.S (PI F. Menard). The proposal has been slightly adapted to match the new array configurations but the requested angular resolution, sensitivity and science goals remain identical. In the advent that this programme finally gets executed in full later in Cycle 2, then it would not need to be re-executed in Cycle 3. No duplication needed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
